ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
c_compiler:
- gcc
c_compiler_version:
- '14'
c_stdlib:
- sysroot
c_stdlib_version:
- '2.17'
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
cxx_compiler:
- gxx
cxx_compiler_version:
- '14'
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64
zip_keys:
- - c_compiler_version
  - cxx_compiler_version

about.summary: A toolkit to predict antimicrobial peptides from protein sequences on a genome-wide scale. It incorporates two support vector machine models ("precursor" and "mature") trained on publicly available antimicrobial peptide data using calculated physico-chemical and compositional sequence properties described in Meher et al. (2017) <doi:10.1038/srep42362>. In order to support genome-wide analyses, these models are designed to accept any type of protein as input and calculation of compositional properties has been optimised for high-throughput use. For best results it is important to select the model that accurately represents your sequence type: for full length proteins, it is recommended to use the default "precursor" model. The alternative, "mature", model is best suited for mature peptide sequences that represent the final antimicrobial peptide sequence after post-translational processing. For details see Fingerhut et al. (2020) <doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btaa653>. The 'ampir' package is also available via a Shiny based GUI at <https://ampir.marine-omics.net/>.

name: r-ampir

about.summary: A toolkit to predict antimicrobial peptides from protein sequences on a genome-wide scale. It incorporates two support vector machine models ("precursor" and "mature") trained on publicly available antimicrobial peptide data using calculated physico-chemical and compositional sequence properties described in Meher et al. (2017) <doi:10.1038/srep42362>. In order to support genome-wide analyses, these models are designed to accept any type of protein as input and calculation of compositional properties has been optimised for high-throughput use. For best results it is important to select the model that accurately represents your sequence type: for full length proteins, it is recommended to use the default "precursor" model. The alternative, "mature", model is best suited for mature peptide sequences that represent the final antimicrobial peptide sequence after post-translational processing. For details see Fingerhut et al. (2020) <doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btaa653>. The 'ampir' package is also available via a Shiny based GUI at <https://ampir.marine-omics.net/>.

raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = '1.1.0' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-ampir
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/ampir_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/ampir/ampir_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: d2c1ad0f0aebf4525fe7c72ccf34a0b69b7e4c850bc57165ce2ed4816deeda5a

build:
  number: 5
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/
  missing_dso_whitelist:
    - '*/R.dll'        # [win]
    - '*/Rblas.dll'    # [win]
    - '*/Rlapack.dll'  # [win]

requirements:
  build:
    - cross-r-base {{ r_base }}    # [build_platform != target_platform]
    - r-peptides                   # [build_platform != target_platform]
    - r-rcpp                       # [build_platform != target_platform]
    - r-caret                      # [build_platform != target_platform]
    - r-kernlab                    # [build_platform != target_platform]
    - {{ compiler('c') }}          # [not win]
    - {{ stdlib("c") }}            # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}    # [win]
    - {{ stdlib("m2w64_c") }}      # [win]
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}        # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_cxx') }}  # [win]
    - {{ posix }}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{ posix }}make
    - {{ posix }}sed               # [win]
    - {{ posix }}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-peptides
    - r-rcpp
    - r-caret >=6.0.0
    - r-kernlab
  run:
    - r-base
    - r-peptides
    - r-rcpp
    - r-caret >=6.0.0
    - r-kernlab

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('ampir')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('ampir')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/Legana/ampir
  license: GPL-2.0-or-later
  summary: 'A toolkit to predict antimicrobial peptides from protein sequences on a genome-wide
    scale. It incorporates two support vector machine models ("precursor" and "mature")
    trained on publicly available antimicrobial peptide data using calculated physico-chemical
    and compositional sequence properties described in Meher et al. (2017) <doi:10.1038/srep42362>.
    In order to support genome-wide analyses, these models are designed to accept any
    type of protein as input and calculation of compositional properties has been optimised
    for high-throughput use. For best results it is important to select the model that
    accurately represents your sequence type: for full length proteins, it is recommended
    to use the default "precursor" model. The alternative, "mature", model is best suited
    for mature peptide sequences that represent the final antimicrobial peptide sequence
    after post-translational processing. For details see Fingerhut et al. (2020) <doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btaa653>.
    The ''ampir'' package is also available via a Shiny based GUI at <https://ampir.marine-omics.net/>.'
  license_family: GPL2
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-2'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r
    - jasmezz
